segment.source: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.
segment.target: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.

segment.source: Guidelines for radio buttons
segment.target: Guidelines for radio buttons

segment.source: Radio buttons
segment.target: Radio buttons

segment.source: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.
segment.target: Radio buttons let users select one option from two or more choices.

segment.source: Each option is represented by one radio button; a user can select only one radio button in a radio button group.
segment.target: Each option is represented by one radio button; a user can select only one radio button in a radio button group.

segment.source: (If you're curious about the name, radio buttons are named for the channel preset buttons on a radio.)
segment.target: (If you're curious about the name, radio buttons are named for the channel preset buttons on a radio.)

segment.source: Radio buttons
segment.target: Radio buttons

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: RadioButton class
segment.target: RadioButton class

segment.source: Checked event
segment.target: Checked event

segment.source: IsChecked property
segment.target: IsChecked property

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: Use radio buttons to present users with two or more mutually exclusive options, as here.
segment.target: Use radio buttons to present users with two or more mutually exclusive options, as here.

segment.source: A group of radio buttons
segment.target: A group of radio buttons

segment.source: Radio buttons add clarity and weight to very important options in your app.
segment.target: Radio buttons add clarity and weight to very important options in your app.

segment.source: Use radio buttons when the options being presented are important enough to command more screen space and where the clarity of the choice demands very explicit options.
segment.target: Use radio buttons when the options being presented are important enough to command more screen space and where the clarity of the choice demands very explicit options.

segment.source: Radio buttons emphasize all options equally, and that may draw more attention to the options than necessary.
segment.target: Radio buttons emphasize all options equally, and that may draw more attention to the options than necessary.

segment.source: Consider using other controls, unless the options deserve extra attention from the user.
segment.target: Consider using other controls, unless the options deserve extra attention from the user.

segment.source: For example, if the default option is recommended for most users in most situations, use a drop-down list instead.
segment.target: For example, if the default option is recommended for most users in most situations, use a drop-down list instead.

segment.source: If there are only two mutually exclusive options, combine them into a single checkbox or toggle switch.
segment.target: If there are only two mutually exclusive options, combine them into a single checkbox or toggle switch.

segment.source: For example, use a checkbox for "I agree" instead of two radio buttons for "I agree" and "I don't agree."
segment.target: For example, use a checkbox for "I agree" instead of two radio buttons for "I agree" and "I don't agree."

segment.source: Two ways of presenting a binary choice
segment.target: Two ways of presenting a binary choice

segment.source: When the user can select multiple options, use a checkbox or list box control instead.
segment.target: When the user can select multiple options, use a checkbox or list box control instead.

segment.source: Selecting multiple options with check boxes
segment.target: Selecting multiple options with check boxes

segment.source: Don't use radio buttons when the options are numbers that have fixed steps, like 10, 20, 30.
segment.target: Don't use radio buttons when the options are numbers that have fixed steps, like 10, 20, 30.

segment.source: Use a slider control instead.
segment.target: Use a slider control instead.

segment.source: If there are more than 8 options, use a drop-down list, a single-select list box, or a list box instead.
segment.target: If there are more than 8 options, use a drop-down list, a single-select list box, or a list box instead.

segment.source: If the available options are based on the app’s current context, or can otherwise vary dynamically, use a single-select list box instead.
segment.target: If the available options are based on the app’s current context, or can otherwise vary dynamically, use a single-select list box instead.

segment.source: Example
segment.target: Example

segment.source: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings.
segment.target: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings.

segment.source: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings
segment.target: Radio buttons in the Microsoft Edge browser settings

segment.source: Create a radio button
segment.target: Create a radio button

segment.source: Radio buttons work in groups.
segment.target: Radio buttons work in groups.

segment.source: There are 2 ways you can group radio button controls:
segment.target: There are 2 ways you can group radio button controls:

segment.source: Put them inside the same parent container.
segment.target: Put them inside the same parent container.

segment.source: Set the GroupName property on each radio button to the same value.
segment.target: Set the GroupName property on each radio button to the same value.

segment.source: NoteA group of radio buttons behaves like a single control when accessed via the keyboard.
segment.target: NoteA group of radio buttons behaves like a single control when accessed via the keyboard.

segment.source: Only the selected choice is accessible using the Tab key but users can cycle through the group using arrow keys.
segment.target: Only the selected choice is accessible using the Tab key but users can cycle through the group using arrow keys.

segment.source: In this example, the first group of radio buttons is implicitly grouped by being in the same stack panel.
segment.target: In this example, the first group of radio buttons is implicitly grouped by being in the same stack panel.

segment.source: The second group is divided between 2 stack panels, so they're explicitly grouped by GroupName.
segment.target: The second group is divided between 2 stack panels, so they're explicitly grouped by GroupName.

segment.source: The radio button groups look like this.
segment.target: The radio button groups look like this.

segment.source: Radio buttons in two groups
segment.target: Radio buttons in two groups

segment.source: A radio button has two states: selected or cleared.
segment.target: A radio button has two states: selected or cleared.

segment.source: When a radio button is selected, its IsChecked property is true.
segment.target: When a radio button is selected, its IsChecked property is true.

segment.source: When a radio button is cleared, its IsChecked property is false.
segment.target: When a radio button is cleared, its IsChecked property is false.

segment.source: A radio button can be cleared by clicking another radio button in the same group, but it cannot be cleared by clicking it again.
segment.target: A radio button can be cleared by clicking another radio button in the same group, but it cannot be cleared by clicking it again.

segment.source: However, you can clear a radio button programmatically by setting its IsChecked property to false.
segment.target: However, you can clear a radio button programmatically by setting its IsChecked property to false.

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: Make sure that the purpose and current state of a set of radio buttons is clear.
segment.target: Make sure that the purpose and current state of a set of radio buttons is clear.

segment.source: Always give visual feedback when the user taps a radio button.
segment.target: Always give visual feedback when the user taps a radio button.

segment.source: Give visual feedback as the user interacts with radio buttons.
segment.target: Give visual feedback as the user interacts with radio buttons.

segment.source: Normal, pressed, checked, and disabled are examples of radio button states.
segment.target: Normal, pressed, checked, and disabled are examples of radio button states.

segment.source: A user taps a radio button to activate the related option.
segment.target: A user taps a radio button to activate the related option.

segment.source: Tapping an activated option doesn’t deactivate it, but tapping another option transfers activation to that option.
segment.target: Tapping an activated option doesn’t deactivate it, but tapping another option transfers activation to that option.

segment.source: Reserve visual effects and animations for touch feedback, and for the checked state; in the unchecked state, radio button controls should appear unused or inactive (but not disabled).
segment.target: Reserve visual effects and animations for touch feedback, and for the checked state; in the unchecked state, radio button controls should appear unused or inactive (but not disabled).

segment.source: Limit the radio button’s text content to a single line.
segment.target: Limit the radio button’s text content to a single line.

segment.source: You can customize the radio button’s visuals to display a description of the option in smaller font size below the main line of text.
segment.target: You can customize the radio button’s visuals to display a description of the option in smaller font size below the main line of text.

segment.source: If the text content is dynamic, consider how the button will resize and what will happen to visuals around it.
segment.target: If the text content is dynamic, consider how the button will resize and what will happen to visuals around it.

segment.source: Use the default font unless your brand guidelines tell you to use another.
segment.target: Use the default font unless your brand guidelines tell you to use another.

segment.source: Enclose the radio button in a label element so that tapping the label selects the radio button.
segment.target: Enclose the radio button in a label element so that tapping the label selects the radio button.

segment.source: Place the label text after the radio button control, not before or above it.
segment.target: Place the label text after the radio button control, not before or above it.

segment.source: Consider customizing your radio buttons.
segment.target: Consider customizing your radio buttons.

segment.source: By default, a radio button consists of two concentric circles—the inner one filled (and shown when the radio button is checked), the outer one stroked—and some text content.
segment.target: By default, a radio button consists of two concentric circles—the inner one filled (and shown when the radio button is checked), the outer one stroked—and some text content.

segment.source: But we encourage you to be creative.
segment.target: But we encourage you to be creative.

segment.source: Users are comfortable interacting directly with the content of an app.
segment.target: Users are comfortable interacting directly with the content of an app.

segment.source: So you may choose to show the actual content on offer, whether that’s presented with graphics or as subtle textual toggle buttons.
segment.target: So you may choose to show the actual content on offer, whether that’s presented with graphics or as subtle textual toggle buttons.

segment.source: Don't put more than 8 options in a radio button group.
segment.target: Don't put more than 8 options in a radio button group.

segment.source: When you need to present more options, use a drop-down list, list box, or a list view instead.
segment.target: When you need to present more options, use a drop-down list, list box, or a list view instead.

segment.source: Don't put two radio button groups next to each other.
segment.target: Don't put two radio button groups next to each other.

segment.source: When two radio button groups are right next to each other, it's difficult to determine which buttons belong to which group.
segment.target: When two radio button groups are right next to each other, it's difficult to determine which buttons belong to which group.

segment.source: Use group labels to separate them.
segment.target: Use group labels to separate them.

segment.source: Additional usage guidance
segment.target: Additional usage guidance

segment.source: This illustration shows the proper way to position and space radio buttons.
segment.target: This illustration shows the proper way to position and space radio buttons.
